origin_of_ch_char_book: East Asian people would kneel down in front of others to indicate their modesty and humility. Today, the Japanese and Korean still preserve such a custom. They usually sit on their knees in the presence of their elders. (æ¯”, bi, compare) shows two people raising their hands and bowing down on their knees simultaneously. By following others while showing a polite appearance, people compare themselves to each other. (åŒ—, bei, north) means two people standing opposite to each other. One does not follow the otherâ€™s politeness. When people see the sun in the south, the opposite side is the north. So this means â€˜northâ€™. And when the flesh (è‚‰, rou, flesh) is added to this character (èƒŒ, bei, back; go against), it means â€˜backâ€™, â€˜betrayalâ€™.
humanum_full_description_en:
Jia Jin inscription starts with two " people ", like two " people " side by side, meaning that they will be side by side. The form of " Bi " and " Cong " are similar, and the difference is that the human figures of " Bi " are mostly to the right, and the characters of " Cong " are mostly to the left; while the lower part of the oracle " Bi " is more curved (Qu Wanli).

Oracle is pronounced as "å¦£", which means the spouse of the ancestor, such as "Bi (å¦£) Geng". It also means assistance, "Wang Bi Wang Cheng" means Wang assist or support Wang Cheng (Li Zongkun). Early inscriptions on bronze inscriptions were also commonly referred to as "å¦£", and the usage was the same as that of Oracle. It is also used as a person's name, and also means an assistant, Ban Gui: "Yinai ğ ‚¤ (teacher) Zuo Bi Maofu".

"Said Wen": "Secrecy. Two people follow, and vice versa is comparison. All those who compare are follow the comparison. Aunt, the ancient text is compared." Duan Yucaiyun: "The original meaning is intimate."
humanum_short_description_en: Synopsis: The Jia Jin inscription starts with two " persons ", like two persons side by side, meaning that they will be side by side.
